reviewText: Another TCF Spanish release. It is an excellent 2.35 Cinemascope DVD, highlyrecommended.  However, see my comments under King of the Khyber rifles about thelack of films like this in the USA and UK markets.

reviewText: This one is really odd. Alan Ladd plays a bitter sheriff out to destroy the town he feels helped kill his wife by denying her medicine. Interesting to see Ladd (who looks bloated) as a bad guy. OK but no more. Ratio is wide-screen 2.35.

reviewText: This is a good Western starring Alan Ladd and Don Murray. Let me say that this release is not a Pan&Scan like other Fox Cinema Archive releases and this is in 2.35:1 Widescreen format. This movie is also presented in color and runs for about 90mins. This movie also star: Dan O'Herlihy, Dolores Michaels, Barry Coe, Larry Gates, plus others! There isn't any special features and it only has English audio with no other languages and no subtitles. Overall this is a good Western and I would recommend this.
Title: N/A

reviewText: A film that received little audience attention - comes via Fox Archive in its original Cinemascope format.  Inexplicably Fox have released many 'Scope films in pan and scan but this one is a fairly good transfer.  Alan Ladd is  out of character in an unsympathetic role in a film that does not gell. Worth investing in only if you are a Ladd or Don Murray fan wanting a good Cinemascope western transfer.
Title: N/A

reviewText: When an impoverished man (Alan Ladd) brings his ill and pregnant wife (Rachel Stephens) to a new town, their indifference and lack of compassion results in his wife's death. Feeling guilty, the town offers penance by making him a deputy sheriff and welcome him into the community. While on the surface a model citizen, he secretly plots a terrible revenge on the town to avenge his wife. To this end, he recruits a drunken ex-soldier (Don Murray), a prostitute (Dolores Michaels) and two gunslingers (Dan O'Herlihy, Barry Coe). While an intriguing and fresh premise for a western, this is no HIGH PLAINS DRIFTER. Ladd, in his most unsympathetic role, isn't a strong enough actor to register the rage simmering underneath his complacent surface. It doesn't help that he looks terrible, aged and bloated. The director James B. Clark doesn't have the edginess that would have increased the tension quotient that a film like this requires. Still, the intriguing posit is enticing enough to keep one entertained through out it all. William C. Mellor (A PLACE IN THE SUN,) did the CinemaScope lensing and Dominic Frontiere is responsible for the routine score. With Larry Gates and Karl Swenson.The Fox DVD from Spain is a decent anamorphic wide screen CinemaScope (2.35) transfer with both English and Spanish audio options.
summary: Alan Ladd in a rare unsympathetic role
Title: N/A
